item.title: Attributes in C/C++
item.description: __attribute__ # In C/C++, one can apply an attribute to a function or a variable using a keyword __attribute__. While it is not part of ISO C standard, popular compilers such as Clang and GCC support it. So, an attribute supported by these two compilers need not be modified. [[attribute]] # There is another syntax for attributes that is introduced since C23 and C++11, which is [[attribute]]. Attribute Namespace # Unlike __attribute__, this syntax requires a namespace to be specified for non-standard attributes as below:

item.title: Static Objects and Undefined Behaviors in C++
item.description: Definition of static objects # Let me start this article with the definition of static objects. A static object refers to a object with a static storage duration. Specifically, it is unique by existence and will exist throughout the execution of a program. static objects in practice # Then, what are static objects in C++? There are mainly two types of static objects: those with internal linkage and the other with external linkage.

item.title: My First Post
item.description: Hello, this is my first post on GitHub blog. This site is powered by Hugo, a static site generator. Here is an example $$ \LaTeX $$ code to test whether it works on Markdown: $$ \begin{align*} f(x) &= x^2\ g(x) &= \frac{1}{x}\ F(x) &= \int^a_b \frac{1}{3}x^3 \end{align*} $$ KaTeX is the $$ \LaTeX $$ rendering engine used for my blog.
